sen.j: 和讃（わさん）は、仏・菩薩や祖師・先徳、経典・教義などを日本語で讃歎した讃歌。
sen.e: Wasan means an anthem which was Buddha, Bosatsu, Soshi (founder of a sect), ancient virtue, Buddhist scriptures, creed were sang by sandan (to praise Buddha's virtues) in Japanese.

Wasan means an anthem sung in Japanese to praise Buddha, Bosatsu, Soshi (founder of a sect), ancient virtue, Buddhist scriptures, creed, etc.

sen.e: Many of the Wasan is made by poem in the seven-five syllable meter, and is chanted with the rhyme which was popular in the period when the Wasan was made.

sen.j: 創作は古く平安時代にさかのぼり、「法華讃歎」「百石（ももさか）讃歎」などが流行した。
sen.e: The Wasan was made in old time of Heian period, there were popular Wasan called 'Hokke sandan' or 'Momosaka'.

sen.e: The Wasan was widely recognized with the propagation, and was popular in various sect of Kamakura Bukkyo. (new Buddhist movements of the Kamakura Period)

sen.j: 浄土真宗の親鸞作の「三帖和讃」（浄土和讃・高僧和讃・正像末和讃）や、時宗の一遍作「別願讃」や他阿作「往生讃」などを含む「浄業（じょうごう）和讃」などが代表である。
sen.e: The well known Wasan are 'Sanjo wasan (three Buddhist verses)' (Jodo-wasan, Koso wasan, Shozomatsu-wasan) of Jodo shin shu (True Pure Land Sect Buddhism) made by Shinran, or Jogo Wasan including 'Betsugan san' of Jishu Sect (Ippen), 'Ojo san' of Taa.

The well known Wasan are 'Sanjo wasan (three Buddhist verses)' (Jodo-wasan, Koso wasan, Shozomatsu-wasan) of Jodo shin shu (True Pure Land Sect Buddhism) made by Shinran, or Jogo Wasan including 'Betsugan san' of Jishu Sect (Ippen), 'Ojo san' of Taa.

Famous Wasan were 'Sanjo wasan' (three Buddhist verses) (Jodo-wasan, Koso-wasan, Shozomatsu-wasan) made by Shinran, the founder of the Jodoshinshu sect (True Pure Land Sect Buddhism), 'Jogo Wasan' including 'Betsugan san' by Ippen of the Jishu sect and 'Ojo san' by Taa.

sen.j: こうした和讃は、広く民衆の間に流布し、日本の音楽に大きな影響を与え、民謡や歌謡、ことに演歌などの歌唱法に影響の形跡が残っている。
sen.e: Such Wasan widely got about within ordinary people and gave big influence to Japanese music, especially there is still traces of such influences in the singing method of Minyo (a traditional folk song), songs and ballads, Enka. (Japanese ballad).

Such Wasan widely influenced ordinary people and had a big influence on Japanese music, and especially there are still traces of such influences in the singing method of Minyo (a traditional folk song), songs and ballads, Enka. (Japanese ballad).

Such Wasan chants became widely influential among ordinary people and affected Japanese music greatly; their effect can be still found in the singing methods of Minyo (traditional folk songs), songs and ballads, especially Enka (Japanese ballad).
